subdebate.1.para: Motion (by Mr. McEwen) - by leave - proposed -

quote.para: That the bill be now read a third time.

talk.start.para: .- I congratulate the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) on the courtesy and co-operation that he has shown in putting this bill through the House. He has set an example to many of his colleagues in the Government. Quite a number of bills have been put through this House in the last few weeks, and the Minister in charge of the bill has not always stood up and answered the questions raised by honorable members on this side of the chamber. On behalf of the Opposition, I thank the Minister for answering, to the best of his knowledge and experience, the questions that have been raised during the debate on this bill.

The tariff proposals which I have tabled relate to proposed amendments to the Customs Tariff 1933-1963, the Customs Tariff (Canada Preference) 1960-1963, and the Customs Tariff (New Zealand Preference) 1933-1963. They will take effect from to-morrow morning. The proposals implement the Government's decisions on the following Tariff Board reports, which will be tabled later to-day, as follows: -

Proposals No. 98 - Engraving blocks, &c.
Proposals No. 99 - Linen fabrics.
Proposals No. 100 - Printing of silk piece goods..

Following international consultations and talks with representatives of both manufacturing and importing sections of the Australian paper industry, proposals No. 95 spells out in a more practical manner the changes recommended by the Tariff Board in its report on paper and paperboard which was tabled on 17th April this year. Briefly, the changes involved in the proposals, which are in accordance with the recommendation of the Tariff Board in each case, are as follows: On refrigerating appliance parts increased protection is imposed on sealed motor units up to 2 horsepower. Otherwise duties revert to the level applying before the temporary duties were imposed. In respect of television receiver components minimum duties of 25s. each and 10s. each, respectively, are imposed on channel tuners for television receivers and deflection yokes for cathode ray tubes. For vinyl acetate the duties are imposed at a level of £57 a ton most favoured nation tariff. This is higher than the ordinary duties previously applying but lower than the combined ordinary and temporary duties.

Consequent on the. implementation of the Tariff Board report on glycerine, fatty acids, soaps and other detergents, duties have been increased on refined glycerine, oleic acid, stearic acid and on organic surfaceactive agents and preparations thereof. Crude glycerine remains admissible at non-protective rates of duty while the duties on crude tall oil, which is not produced in Australia, are being removed entirely. The protective duties on soaps remain unchanged.

On floor coverings of linoleum, cork, vinyl, rubber, asbestos and like compositions, the changes recommended by the Tariff Board in general provide moderately increased protection against competition from the main source, of imports. On engravers' blocks, the board has again recommended a moderate increase in protection against imports from the main source of competition affecting the production in Australia of engravers' zinc plates.

Linen fabrics become dutiable at ad valorem rates of 371/2 per cent. British preferential tariff and 471/2 per cent intermediate tariff in lieu of the existing cumulative duties. Prepared painting canvas, which is not produced in Australia, becomes admissible at non-protective rates of free British preferential tariff and 71/2 per cent otherwise. Increased protection of 9d. a square yard is accorded for the printing of silk piece goods in accordance with the Tariff Board's recommendations.

The tariff changes in Proposals No. 95 relating to paper merely allocate the Tariff Board's basic recommendations for coated paper and paperboards in a somewhat more sophisticated manner. The extra divisions have the full support of Australian paper manufacturers and importers.

I commend the proposals to honorable members. The Government proposes to validate the collection of duties imposed under these proposals until 30th June, 1964, by means of a bill to be, submitted to the Parliament shortly. The proposals will have to be re-introduced into the new Parliament and will subsequently be open for debate in the visual manner.

talk.start.para: .- The Copper Bounty Bill was introduced this morning by the Minister for Supply (Mr. Fairhall). It implements recommendations of the Tariff Board which were made recently after an inquiry into the copper industry. Payment of the bounty will be extended for a further two years from 1st January, 1964. The industry will continue to receive assistance through a combination of the bounty and a duty. The duty operates when the overseas price of copper falls below £290 a ton. The bounty rate of £35 a ton applies when the overseas price of copper is £290 a ton or less. The Labour Party strongly supports the measure. It is of great importance not only to Tasmania but also to other areas. It is of particular importance to the west coast of Tasmania where Queenstown, with a population of about 5,000, Gormanston and the port of Strahan are almost entirely dependent for their existence on the well-being and prosperity of the Mount Lyell copper mine.

speech.para: The Tariff Board's report which was presented to the Parliament this morning recognizes this state of affairs. On page 21 of the report it is said -

quote.para: Without bounty assistance to Mount Lyell, the population of Queenstown, Gormanston and Strahan would be forced to move to other centres, the nearest being more than '100 miles away, and substantial public and private capital would be lost.

speech.para: It has been estimated that the replacement value of the property and public amenities in the district, even after excluding State roads and the company's operating buildings and installations is about £10,000,000.

I want to pay the highest possible tribute to all associated with Mount Lyell. It works on the lowest grade of copper ore being used anywhere in the world. It is because of the excellent management of Mr. H. Murray - and of his father before him - and because of the excellent employer-employee relationship that the mine has been able to operate and play such an important part in the economic life of this country. The Tariff Board's report, which has led to the legislation before us this afternoon, recognizes the efficiency and the high degree of management skill displayed at the mine. At page 10 of the report the board states -

quote.para: Improvements in the company's operating efficiency have been achieved at the various stages of production. For example, at the mining stage, trucking costs per' ton have been reduced by 39 per cent., and the tons of material moved per man shift increased from 34.3 in 1959 to 36.4 in 1963. Also the recovery from milling and treatment has increased by the equivalent of approximately 720 tons of copper per year, representing an increase of net revenue of £140,000 per year.
Coke consumption by the company's smelter decreased by 28 per cent, per ton of copper between 1959 and 1963, equivalent to a cost saving of £90,000 per year.

Mount Lyell recently ceased its railway operations, and is now relying on road transport for haulage to. and from Strahan. The company expects that this will reduce costs by £120,000 per annum. As well, a study of operating and maintenance methods and techniques is being undertaken in all departments, and Mount Lyell anticipates that appreciable cost reductions will result.

speech.para: We are sorry to see the railway line go. lt linked the mining town of Queenstown with the port of Strahan. It was operated by the Abt system. A cog lowered from underneath the engine fitted into a saw-toothed arrangement between the two rails. By this means the train was hauled up through about 6 miles of very picturesque country and let down the slope on the other side. It was the only train of its type anywhere in Australia. As well as transporting the products of the company to Strahan, it hauled passenger carriages. A trip in this train through 26 miles of beautiful country to Strahan was looked forward to and experienced with a great deal of pleasure by tourists from all over the world. However, because of competition from Mount Isa and other mines the Mount Lyell company has been forced to give up the railway line. Its products are now transported to Strahan by road. Various attempts were made to keep the railway line open, but when you consider that its closure will save the mining company £120,000 a year, you see that the closure was inevitable.

Such a saving must be particularly considered by a mining company which operates on the lowest grade of copper ore worked anywhere in the world to-day. At Mount Lyell the copper content of the ore is .7 per cent. At Mount Morgan it is about 1 per cent. At Mount Isa it is 3 per cent, and at Peko, in the Northern Territory, it is 6 per cent. Last year the Mount Isa company treated almost 2,000,000 tons of ore and recovered 55,000 tons of copper. At Mount Lyell more than 2,000,000 tons of ore was treated, but the copper recovered was only one-quarter of the recovery at Mount Isa. About 13,344 tons of copper was recovered at Mount Lyell from the treatment of 2,000,000 tons of ore. The estimated average ratio of waste to ore is .83 to one at Mount Lyell. This means that the company must remove almost 1,000,000 tons of overburden and almost 1,500,000 tons of ore to produce 10,000 tons of copper. These figures stress the high degree of efficiency of the mining operations at Mount Lyell. I consider that the Tariff Board has acted correctly in recommending assistance to the industry. The Mount Lyell mine is recognized in mining circles throughout the world as being possibly the most efficient mine operating in the world to-day.

The bounty provided for in this legislation is payable only on copper sold in Australia. In their statements to the Tariff Board, the Copper Producers Association, the Mount Lyell company and the Mount Morgan company all requested that the bounty be paid on the production of copper in Australia, rather than on sales of copper in Australia. Until a few years ago, the Mount Lyell company was practically the sole producer of copper in Australia. So the bounty applied to every ton of copper produced by that company. But, in recent years, Mount Isa Mines Limited has increased its production tremendously and has now taken a great share of the Australian market. Production at Mount Isa has risen from about 40,000 tons four years ago to more than 55,000 tons last year. The capacity of the mine and the smelter at Mount Isa is about 75,000 tons of copper a year. Further expansion that is under way there will be completed in the financial year 1966-67. This will allow for an annual production of 100,000 tons of copper at Mount Isa.

When we consider that the demand in Australia is for only 50,000 to 55,000 tons a year, we realize that the proportion of the output of some companies taken by the home market is diminishing and that they must export more of their finished product. The fact that the proportion of production exported does not qualify for bounty, and the fact that the increased production of various mines has forced them to export more, no doubt led the copper producers at Mount Isa, Mount Morgan and Mount Lyell to put to the Tariff Board the submission that bounty be made payable on all copper produced in Australia rather than just on the proportion of output sold here. I mention this because it is estimated that, in 1965, Australia will produce about 130,000 tons of copper. Since at least half of that will be exported, only half the production will qualify for bounty under the present arrangements. That presents a problem to these mines in isolated areas, which are doing a wonderful job in developing resources and maintaining outback communities. So this problem will have to be looked at again, Sir.

The Mount Lyell company, in its submission to the Tariff Board, requested that the cost of removing waste over the next three years bc charged against operating costs, regardless of the theoretical average of the ratio of waste to ore. But this submission has been rejected. I have already mentioned the huge amount of overburden that has to be removed in operations at Mount Lyell. The removal costs are very considerable, and they have to be debited against some sections of normal mining operations. I do not know whether it is possible at this late hour for the Minister for Supply, who is in charge of the bill, to tell me why these costs cannot be charged against operating costs. Perhaps he can let us have some information about this when he replies to the debate.

The continuing of the bounty for the next two years is a wonderful thing for the mines at Mount Lyell, Mount Morgan and elsewhere. We of the Australian Labour Party wholeheartedly support the measure. However, I would have liked more time to examine various aspects of it. I am sure the Minister appreciates that, as it was presented to us this morning and as we have to dispose of it this afternoon, time is too limited for closer examination of its provisions and more detailed discussion of the effects on some of the mining companies of the non-payment of bounty on the proportion of output exported. I understand that only one copy of the Tariff Board's report is available, and I greatly appreciate the Minister's co-operation and courtesy in enabling me to examine it. Having looked through the report, I realize that the board has considered certain matters in arriving at its recommendation that the rate of bounty be the same as the rate paid for the last two years.

I should have liked, also, to examine more closely the effects of the bill on the position of the smaller producers and various other aspects of it. I point out that the present act will expire on the last day of this year. Therefore, with an election to be held shortly and the possibility that the Parliament will not meet again until next year, after some months have passed, it is important to the economic life of the people and the districts concerned that this measure be passed. The Tariff Board has recommended that the bounty continue at the same rate as before, and that will be of undoubted benefit to the company at Mount Lyell and the mines at Mount Morgan and elsewhere that produce copper. For these reasons, as I have said, we on this side of the chamber heartily support the bill.

At this stage, Sir, I should like to pay tribute to the Tariff Board. It has shown by the conduct of its inquiry that it appreciates the wonderful work that is being done by the mining companies in remote areas and in earning export income by the export of copper, which is an important export commodity for Australia. Although, as I have said, I would have liked time to examine certain matters in more detail, I certainly have no complaint about this measure. I realize how important it is, and how beneficial it will be, particularly to the Mount Lyell company which, as I have said, mines the lowest grade copper ore in the world. The bounty will be very valuable indeed to that company. Perhaps a member on my side of the House should not commend this Government so close to election day, but I commend the Government on the introduction of this bill.

talk.start.para: .- Mr. Speaker, I do not propose to detain the House long in speaking in support of this bill. The honorable member for Braddon (Mr. Davies) has just stated the position of Mount Isa Mines Limited but the effect on the gougers' mines in the Mount Isa area is the aspect of the measure with which I am particularly concerned. This bill results from a Tariff Board inquiry. In 1960, a similar measure was introduced after a Tariff Board inquiry. On that occasion, the board recommended that legislation be enacted to enable bounty to be paid for five years, but the Government decided that it would provide for bounty to be paid only for three years. Now, after another Tariff Board inquiry, this bill will give effect to the Tariff Board's recommendation in 1958 that bounty be paid for five years.

speech.para: The Minister for Supply (Mr. Fairhall), in his second-reading speech said -

quote.para: The board has made its recommendation for continuation of the existing rate of bounty as, in effect, a holding action for the next two years. By that time, the position in regard to the potential new mine at Cobar, New South Wales, and its effect as a new major producer on domestic and export sales of the present mines, will be clearer and easier to assess.

speech.para: If the Government is honest and sincere about its desire to encourage development, why should what happens at Cobar have any effect on the payment of a bounty to a small producer elsewhere? This bil] will benefit only those who produce 100 tons over two years. Why should they be adversely affected by what happens at Cobar? As I have said, this bill provides for the payment of a bounty to the small producer.

We know what the mining industry has done for the north-west of western Queensland. The honorable member for Braddon referred to the development of Mount Isa. That is one example of the development which follows mining. The Mary Kathleen, which is suspending operations temporarily, is another indication of what mining has done in an isolated and under-populated part of Queensland. Therefore, irrespective of what happens at Cobar or any other place, why should not every possible encouragement be given to the small producer? Indeed, the bounty should be paid not only on the copper sold on the domestic market but on all copper produced by the small producers.

talk.start.para: - Before the suspension of the sitting, 1 referred to the fact that mining had led to the settlement of a virile population in the sparsely settled areas of north-west Queensland. Such centres of population can be found at Mount Isa and Mary Kathleen, which are two very fine towns. The limitation of 100 tons over a period of two years will mean that quite a number of copper gougers or small producers will be covered by the bill, if they can have their ore treated and sold on the domestic market. These men work more than 600 miles west of Townsville. The only place where they can sell their ore is at Mount Isa. However, Mount lsa Mines Limited has placed a limit on the amount of customs ore that it will buy, because it has its own ore to treat. In consequence, many men who have leases are unable to sell their ore. In addition, Mount Isa Mines Limited has decided that if there is the slightest suggestion of a nickel content in the copper ore, it will not buy the customs ore. The only places the miners can sell this rejected ore are Mount Morgan, which is about 1 ,000 miles away, or Port Kembla, in New South Wales. ' If they sent their ore to these places, they would be working for the railways, because freight would take any money they received for the ore.

speech.para: If the miners were allowed to sell their ore on the export market as well as on the domestic market, many leases which to-day are not Being worked would be worked. Japanese buyers are on the Cloncurry field now negotiating with the copper cooperative, which was formed a few years ago by the gougers on the field. The gougers wanted to have a treatment plant established so that they could develop their leases. I know that it is of no use appealing to this Government now, because we are only four weeks away from an election. However, after 30th November, a more sympathetic government will take office and it will give favorable consideration to the requests of these small gougers who are covered by the bill. Irrespective of where their ore is sold, whether on the domestic market or the export market, they should receive the bounty. This would have a twofold effect. The production of copper would be increased and this would mean the development of an area in which the Government says it is interested - that is, the north of Australia. In addition, the town of Cloncurry would be developed. This, of course, is only one centre of population in the area. The business people in the town would derive some benefit from the increased local income, and the whole of the Australian economy would benefit because these people would be selling their copper overseas and helping to increase our overseas balances.

The Minister, in his second-reading speech, said that this bounty would cost between £490,000 and £660,000 in a year. If the incoming government agrees to pay the copper bounty to the small people producing up to 100 tons in two years, the whole of the community will derive some benefit. Miners' costs are very high. The lorries used to cart the ore from the leases to Mount Isa are very costly. They travel through areas where there are no roads or, in some cases, even bush tracks. The wear and tear on tires is very heavy. In consequence, the cost of the transport of ore is high. 1 know that the incoming government will give sympathetic consideration to the suggestions I have made. Whoever produces the ore should receive the bounty, whether the ore is sold on the domestic market or on the export market.

I do not wish to detain the House any longer. I have been told that I am the second last man in. The wicket is playing very well and there are plenty of runs in it. 1 know that on 30th November the Australian Labour Party will score a record number of runs.

talk.start.para: . - I want to say just a few words on the bill in the dying hours of the Parliament. This measure is important to the Northern Territory. A substantial bounty such as that provided in the bill would result in hundreds of small mines in the Northern Territory being worked. We in the Northern Territory at this time want mineral production more than anything else. The bill will enable small producers to take advantage of facilities such as the treatment plant at Rum Jungle when the mine there ceases to produce uranium. The mining of uranium ore there has ceased, but ore is still being treated. The Government announced recently that the treatment plant at Rum Jungle will be made available for the treatment of ores from other places.

speech.para: We in the Northern Territory believe that hundreds of deposits of copper ore would be worked if the facilities for treatment were available on an economic basis. We have asked the Government to provide bonuses and subsidies for the treatment of the ore, because it has to be carted over distances of 100 to 150 miles - from places far afield - to the treatment plant. Subsidies such as that, together with the subsidy granted in this bill, would give a distinct advantage to copper producers. We know that gold is a very attractive proposition, but the mining of base metal ore bodies leads to the establishment of centres of population. In the mining of copper, lead, zinc and similar materials, we have the best means of creating work and establishing towns.

talk.start.para: - Would you say that copper is one of the main metals?

- Yes, it is one of the principal metals. It is an export commodity that could provide big exchange benefits for this nation. In addition, it could create, as Mount Isa and other copper fields have shown, the means of developing centres of population. No other activity could give the same benefit.

speech.para: We support the measure. We support any measure that will encourage the production of any base metal or gold. In this instance, a bounty is being paid for a base metal. I join with my colleague, the honorable member for Kennedy (Mr. Riordan), in saying that we welcome this proposition. This and other forms of assistance given on a consistent and long-term basis will increase mining activities in- the Northern Territory. If this assistance were not given, these activities would not be undertaken. There are other types of ore such as silver, silver-lead, zinc and so on, but copper is a commodity that has a world-wide attraction. The sale of our copper overseas cams exchange for Australia. Copper mining is a means of establishing communities if the Commonwealth Government at this stage provides, in addition to the subsidy, communications in the form of roads and railways, which would benefit not only the Northern Territory but also the rest of Australia.

Before to-day, we had many tariff proposals in the machine, so to speak, founded on twenty Tariff Board reports. This afternoon, another set of proposals, founded on seven more Tariff Board reports, were presented. It is evident that' we will not debate them now. If the reports continue to come in even at considerably less than the present rate of intake, by the time the House again meets, perhaps in the middle of March, we will have 57 reports before us.

speech.para: The reports may not be as interesting to other honorable members as they sometimes are to my morbid mind, but I protest that it is impossible for any one adequately to deal with 57 Tariff Board reports in one tariff debate. There arc limits to the endurance of the House, if not to my endurance, and I do not think such procedure is reasonable. If the House wants these tariff items to be debated seriously as I think they ought to be and democratic processes require that they be so debated this method of proceeding imposes an impossible load on any honorable member, however dedicated or devoted to the subject he may be. I cannot let this bill be passed without entering a protest. Whatever government may be in power in March, the House will have to debate 57 Tariff Board reports.I am not issuing a threat, but it is obvious that some one will have to debate themin some detail. I have had the morbid experience of having to discuss sixteen Tariff Board reports during one debate and it is not a pleasant experience. To debate 57 Tariff Board reports on one occasion would be a mournful experience not only for me but for the whole House.
