talk.start.para: . - Mr. Speaker
- Will ye no conic back again?

- The answer to that question, to use a homely phrase, is " Too right ". But now that we have reached the end of the session, and indeed, the end of the Parliament, I just want to say, on behalf of all honorable members, that we are anxious to express our indebtedness,to you, Sir; to the other presiding officers;to the Clerks at the table who manage to keep us out of an almost incredible amount of trouble; to the members of the " Hansard " staff who record and improve our speeches; to all those who minister to our comfort and our needs, in the Library, in the dining room, in whatever part of the Parliament we may be. We are greatly indebted to all of them.

speech.para: But I never come to the end of a parliament without thinking that we are primarily indebted to each other in Parliament. I think I have had occasion to say before that the few trifling skiffs which cross the water are occasionally magnified, I believe, into very serious trouble. Having been here a long time, I must say that I have not known very much serious trouble. In fact, looking back on my own time, I have known, from both my friends and foes, far more friendship than I have enmity. I think this is a not uncommon experience in this House. We arc going out to attack and battle with each other. If I may say so, I have not failed to notice this week a few vague hints on the conflict to come. All sorts of people will tell us what the results will be, but the electors will tell us all on 30th November. All I want to say now is that I think this has been a very interesting Parliament - very interesting and very difficult, I suppose, for all of us - because almost equally divided parliaments present their own problems, not all of which present themselves on the surface. There is a state of constant tension and difficulty. But speaking as one who has had a long experience of many parliamentary terms, I look back on this one as a term of immense interest. I do not want to say to my opponents that I wish them well except in a personal way. I hope that they remain in good health.

talk.start.para: - Many happy returns?

- Oh, yes! Looking at four or five of my opponents I am confident that they will be back with us. I shall do my best to prevent some of them from coming back and, of course, they will reciprocate the courtesy and do their best to sec that some of my colleagues do not come back. This is all part of the great conflict of politics. All I can say is. that it is a conflict which is the proof of democracy. If we conduct the conflict like honest democrats, fight hard and take f!ie verdict, this will be a wonderful experience for alF. of us.

speech.para: I wish all honorable members a Happy Christmas. Christmas comes 25 days after St; Andrew's Day, and St. Andrew's Day is polling day. I would not have you believe that I am so Scottish as to be superstitious, but I think this is a handsome event. I offer the personal good wishes of all of us to all of our fellow members in this Parliament, because although we are in different parties and we sometimes have violent points of difference, we all are honoured by serving in this Parliament the people of Australia by the choice of the people.

On this occasion one cannot foretell - one never can - what voluntary retirements may occur. I should refer on this occasion to several honorable members who are leaving us. First there is my most valued colleague, the Postmaster-General (Mr. Davidson). He has not had the easiest assignment in the world. He has occasionally encountered troubled waters, but I have pointed out to him more than once that he has a singular advantage over me because if a question is put to me all I have to do is to stand up in my place, which does not give me much time to think of an answer, but my colleague walks all the way from his seat to the table, which gives him time to think of three bad answers, discard them, and come down in favour of a fourth. I have explained this to him many times. Every member pf this House respects him. He is a very fine Australian. He has served Australia in many fields. We are sorry that considerations of health have induced him to leave us.

I will miss greatly seeing the honor::,le member for New England (Mr. Drummond) stand, look at me and say, " I have a question to put to the right honorable the Prime Minister", because I know full well w\at the question will be about. He has had a long and honorable service, not only in this Parliament but also in the Parliament of New South Wales. We shall miss him.

We shall miss also the honorable member for Moore (Mi*. Leslie). His health has been indifferent. He suffers from some physical disabilities which are the pure result of gallantry and patriotism. He has

item.label: a.
item.para: remarkable record of service to our country. I would like him to know that no matter what party wc may belong to, he leaves us with our profound respect.

speech.para: Then of course two veterans on the other side of the House are leaving us, if 1 may refer to them.

talk.start.para: - And the honorable member for Cunningham.

- 1 am indebted to my friend. 1 was thinking, as 1 always do in point of time, first of my old and valued friend, the honorable member for Bonython (Mr. Makin). Here is a man who has been a Minister, a great and zealous member of the Parliament and an ambassador for Australia in a very great country. He has been my constant opponent, except when he was in the Speaker's chair, when he really behaved, 1 thought, with singular impartiality.
- Did he ever put you out?

- The only Speaker who ever put me out was the honorable member for Darling (Mr. Clark). If I may forget for a moment the forms of the House, 1 would like to say to Norman Makin that I will miss him. We all will miss him. We are quite sure that he goes out of parliamentary life, although I dare say not out of public life, with a high spirit and with great pride.

speech.para: The honorable member for Port Adelaide (Mr. Thompson) also is a great friend and a fine member. 1 would like to tell him that only to-day 1 was speaking about him to somebody and I said, " He represents to me one of the finest examples of what I call the classical virtues of the Labour member and the lifetime servant of the Labour movement ". He has complete integrity - we all respect this. He has recovered remarkably from a period of ill health. I hope that he lives for a long, long time.
We are losing also the honorable member for Cunningham (Mr. Kearney). We shall miss him.

It is an extraordinary thing how, as time goes on, we come and we go. I always comfort myself by knowing that when the day comes for me to leave, if I leave on my own flat feet 1 will be surprised to find how many nice things may bc said about me. To-night, however, 1 speak in terms of utter substance. These men who are leaving us, voluntarily as I have said, will leave a great gap in this House. We shall look back on the enjoyment of their company with great pleasure.

Sir, I want to extend my warm good wishes to all those who have tended to our needs - to the Leader of the Opposition and to all members of the House. I thank my colleagues for their most faithful support. Last but not least I want to say that in a parliament that is almost equally divided the Whips have a man-sized job. We have been very fortunate to have such good Whips - such zealous Whips - and in my case such commanding Whips to see that the numbers are right.
Sir, a very Merry Christmas and a Happy New Year to you.

talk.start.para: . - To-night I agree with everything that the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) has said. I may not agree with all that he says from here on - at least until 30th November. He has spoken very fairly, very eloquently and very justly about all the people who serve usabout all the people who minister to us and about those who are with us now for the last time and who, because of ill-health and other reasons, are leaving us. There is always sadness ir departure. There is always sadness in the thought that those who are with us will not be with us if we happen to be among the lucky ones who will come back. The Prime Minister has taken consolation in the fact that 30th November is St. Andrew's Day.

speech.para: Sir Robert Menzies__ Not consolation, dear boy; pride.

talk.start.para: - Well, may I say pride and consolation. After all, he did not go to St. Andrew's Cathedral to be installed; he went to St. Giles's. I do not know when St. Giles's Day happens to fall, but I do know that 1st December is Advent Sunday. I know that the day on which the Prime Minister issues the writs is All Saints Day.
- Obviously that docs not apply.
- I take consolation, pride and hope from the fact that 30th

speech.para: November and 1st December have been honoured at least canonically

For the last two years we have had a balanced Parliament, even if the debates have not always been balanced. We have done the best that we can to carry on the government of the country. There have been losses on our side which we deplored. All honorable members have mourned with us the deaths of three members of this House and one of another place. One never knows the fate of members once elected to a parliament. 1 hope that the next Parliament will be like the Parliament elected in 1946 which in three years did not suffer a death or have any tragedy befall any honorable member. I hope that the next Parliament will be the one that we want to see elected, but whatever the people decide will bc acceptable to us.

The voice of democracy must always be honoured. There are some people in the world, even in the Western world, who still think that the only good government is the one that they want to choose. To me democracy means majority rule. There is nothing sacred about majority rule. It is the principle of order but not necessarily of justice. We can only settle for the proposition that whether the majority be 99 to 1 or 51 to 49, majority rule is the best system of government that we know. The only other system is one of dictatorship or semi-dictatorship. We in the English-speaking world have learned to work along democratic lines, so we will survive. We have been able to make democracy work. That is our great strength.

We have our hopes and sometimes, of course, we have our disappointments. The people will decide the constitution of the 25th Parliament of the Commonwealth on 30th November and we will loyally accept the decision, whatever it may bc. We will fight our fights according to the best of our ability. We will impress our personalities upon our electorates. We will persuade the electors to the best of our ability and then, when the vote is taken, we will say, " Well, the people have made their decision for the next three years". Whatever government is elected to Office, may I express the hope that some move will be made to enlarge this Parliament in a logical manner. May the next government, from whichever side it comes, put to the people the recommendation of the Constitutional Review Committee with respect to the relationship of the two Houses so that ultimately we will be able to enlarge the membership of the Parliament as the population increases.

This Parliament has great responsibilities and it will have greater responsibilities. The process of time will not work in favour of any eroding of Commonwealth powers; it will work in favour of more centralization of power, irrespective of whether State Parliaments and State politicians like it. Perhaps this is not the time to say these things but I am saying them now because I think that the future of this country demands that the National Parliament, which has enormous responsibilities and will have even greater responsibilities in the future, should be large enough to represent the views of the people and the nation.

On behalf of the Opposition, I wish all honorable members a very happy Christmas. I wish them personal good health and good luck. We will try to take seats from honorable members opposite. We have great hopes and expectations. They, too, have great hopes and expectations. Well, we will join issue with them. They will fight their fight; we will fight ours. Ultimately, when the result is known, the people of Australia will be able to say that they have been fully informed during the campaign of all the relevant issues. I trust that no one will be able to say that he cast a vote without first having the fullest information on all the issues involved.

To the Prime Minister, to whom I owe some debt for his personal consideration of requests that I have made to him from time to time on behalf of Opposition members, 1 express my thanks. He has not been unmindful of the Opposition's position in this Parliament. He has played the part of a good parliamentarian. He has recognized that there must be an Opposition in this and in every democratic parliament, because in a democracy the opposition is the alternative government. If we were the government we would have to do the same as he has done. We would be recreant to our duty if we did not do what he has done in the long period in which he has been the Prime Minister of Australia.
There is nothing more that I can do, except to say to the honorable member for
New England (Mr. Drummond) with whom I served on the Constitutional Review Committee, that I hope he lives long enough to see the realization of his dearest dream, which I will not mention.

talk.start.para: .- Mr. Speaker, 1 should like to join with the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) and the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell) in expressing my thanks and the thanks of my party to you for the fair and able manner in which you have presided over the House, and to the Chairman of Committees and your deputies. I join in the expressions of thanks to the staff of " Hansard " and of the Library and to the multitude of other people who service the Parliament - including those who personally serve Ministers. I thank the Leader of the Opposition, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the Whips and all who combine to make the institution of parliament operate. 1 join with the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition in recognizing that, particularly in this 24th Parliament, the Whips have bad a particularly difficult job. Without exception they have discharged their onerous duties most ably, faithfully and fairly.

speech.para: This has been a hard Parliament, but when it commenced we recognized that it would be hard in the personal sense. The calls on us have been more exacting than we have been accustomed to previously, but we have come through. We go presently to give the people an opportunity to choose a government which will command a more comfortable majority in the House. Of course, 1 join with all my friends on this side of the House in hoping, and indeed in being confident, that we will be the people's choice. But we, like the Leader of the Opposition, will accept the verdict of the people as the proper expression of democracy.

This is an occasion of some sadness for me in that I am now speaking in the presence of three of my colleagues who, of their own decision, will not hereafter sit in this Parliament. My deputy leader, the Postmaster-General, the Honorable Charles Davidson, has served this Parliament and our Government with ability, distinction and unchallenged integrity. He has had a difficult portfolio, but 1 think friend and foe alike would say that he has done a jolly good job. His service to this country has not been only in the Parliament. He served this country in the two world wars with great distinction. In fact, there are topographical features in New Guinea known as Charlie's Hill and Davidson's Ridge. So he will be remembered there. He came to us with a very specialized knowledge of the sugar industry, of which he had become one of the great Australian leaders before coming into this Parliament. All of us - and I in particular - will miss our close personal acquaintanceship with the Postmaster-General.

My colleague, the honorable member for New England (Mr. Drummond), chooses to go out of parliamentary life now of his own decision, after a phenomenally long period of 29 years in this Parliament and the Parliament of New South Wales. He served in that State Parliament with distinction. He served in more than one cabinet. He then elected to come into the federal arena and, as we all know, he has served here since 1949 with continuing devotion to the general high standards that he upholds and to the particular objectives that are dear to him - the establishment of new States in New South Wales, the principle of new States generally, the welfare of rural interests and furthering the cause of education in this country. We will miss him, and his contributions to this Parliament will be missed. To-night we thank him

My colleague, the honorable member for Moore (Mr. Leslie), like my other colleagues, has elected not to contest his scat again. He is a man with a great record. He served in his teens with the forces of South Africa in the First World War. He came to Australia and served in the Second World War. He was severely wounded at Tobruk. He has the distinction of belonging to that excellent band, the " Rats of Tobruk ". He turned to the Western Aus; tralian Parliament, in which he served my party with great distinction, as he has done in this Parliament. He has an indomitable fighting spirit. When friend or foc got in his way when he was fighting for what he believed in, he went on fighting. Hugh Leslie will be remembered in this Parliament as a friend, a man of distinction, a man of honour and a man of principle.

We will miss from the Parliament - I certainly shall - the honorable member for Bonython (Mr. Makin). Here is a man who has a tremendous record of service to his party. Of all the present members of this House, he was the earliest elected. He was elected to this Parliament away back in 1919, His period of service has not been continuous, but that is because he assumed another form of office for a period at the request of the government of the day. He has been a Speaker, a Minister and an ambassador. What higher succession of honour could come to any one man? He has brought honour to himself, to his party, to his State, to this country and to this Parliament. We shall miss him.

The honorable member for Port Adelaide (Mr. Thompson) is a man of direct approach and the utmost probity, who has earned the respect of every one in this House. He might well have served in a higher office than those in which he has had an opportunity to serve in this Parliament. We will remember his record as one of service and example to which any one might willingly aspire. The honorable member for Cunningham (Mr. Kearney), unhappily, has not enjoyed good health in recent times. He has served his cause and his party in this House. He has carried the banner of his party in the cause for which he has fought well in this Parliament.

I think it is right, in the difficult life that we all lead, that when men choose to go Gut voluntarily expressions of this kind should be voiced in this Parliament, because there is not much reward other than the satisfaction that one gets from serving in this Parliament, lt is good to think that those with whom they serve are willing and anxious to put on record some recognition of the service performed by them. We see objectives and policies differently; but I believe that without exception the people who come into this Parliament come here to serve. In our membership and candidature, we primarily are attached to political parties; but when we come here we become involved perhaps in bigger policy issues, and certainly in more policy issues, than we comprehended before entering the Parliament. My observation is that without exception people devote, themselves unsparingly and with a surprising degree of dedication to the cause of the country and to the particular cause and policies for which they stand.

Having said these nice things about each other, we will now go out and fight each other in the election campaign. That is not hypocrisy, because we will not be fighting each other as persons; we will be standing in a democratic election for the principles and policies in which we severally believe. No doubt we will fight all the issues in a pretty wholehearted manner; but I believe that all of us will retain within our minds - I am sure that I will retain this in my mind - the thought that we are all citizens of Australia, that win, lose or draw we are still all citizens of Australia and that we will not divide the citizenship of this country. After the new Parliament is chosen and wc come back here, on whatever side of the chamber we sit - I am confident that 1 will sit on this side - wc will continue to perform our parliamentary functions. I join with the Prime Minister and the Leader of the Opposition in saying that for the coming days 1 wish health and strength, and express personal good wishes, to all who go out in the election campaign, and I express especially good wishes, in the political sense, to those who fight on my side.

talk.start.para: - 1 think I should take advantage of this opportunity, first of all, to thank the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell) and the Minister for Trade (Mr. McEwen) for the kindly references that they have made to mc personally and to the staff. It is only by your tolerance and understanding that I am still in office! I can say at this hilarious time that one of the reasons why I am pleased to be here and to have this opportunity to make what is called the annual speech of the Speaker is that I can speak for myself, thank myself and do everything that is completely outside the Standing Orders. When I have finished I have quite a different view of the interpretation of them.

speech.para: On behalf of those people who are not able to speak for themselves, I say how much they appreciate the references that have been made about them. 1 refer, first, to the people connected with the Joint House Department. They include all the people who serve members of this House - the people in the dining room, the people who do the cleaning, the messengers, the guides and all others who render that part of the service to members. I am sure that they enjoy the confidence and the goodwill of everybody with whom they are associated. They do everything they can to honour their obligations and carry out their tasks.

I think I should say a word or two about the Library. We do appreciate the assistance we get from the Library. I am quite satisfied that I do not visit it often enough, and I think this may apply to many of us. The facilities of the Library are always available to honorable members, and the officers of the Library invariably display great courtesy and a willingness to assist.

I also want to say a word or two about our friends of " Hansard ", who really make my speech look respectable, which is no mean feat. We are very grateful to them for the job that they do. I often wonder whether we realize exactly how important they are and what their duties entail. I am sure that every one of us is most grateful to them for protecting us when the electors read our speeches. May I say at this stage that if events transpire according to the wish of some people, we will not have the privilege of having Mr. Dale with us when the House meets again. He will be retiring early in February, and I am sure you would all like me to express to Mr. Dale our appreciation of the very great service that he has given in the department that he has had the honour to control.

Now I come to the most important section of the Parliament, the men who do the work, the men who are responsible for the reputation of the institution from the administrative point of view. I have been associated with many institutions in my time, and I want to say that I have never mct a more efficient, loyal and co-operative group than we have here in Mr. Turner and his staff. In one's dealings with them one senses an atmosphere of very great loyalty and friendship. I am sure we can say to Mr. Turner and all associated with him, right down to the records staff, that we very much appreciate the part they have played in maintaining the reputation of Parliament, in keeping the Speaker on the rails and in seeing that Ministers understand the new Standing Orders.
To those whom I may have missed, I would like to say how grateful we are to them for what they have done for us.

I am going to be very sorry when I see my old friend, the Postmaster-General (Mr. Davidson), go out of this place. Having myself been a lance-corporal in the Army - during the time when I slept for eight hours - I have very great respect for the colonel. 1 entirely agree with the sentiments that have been expressed with regard to the honorable gentleman, and, for the first time, 1 am on side with the officers.

I also wish to take the opportunity of saying au revoir to the honorable member for New England (Mr. Drummond). I think we will all agree that as a member of the burning bush he has made a great contribution to the public and political life of this country, and- that he has also made a great contribution in the educational field.

To the honorable member for Moore (Mr. Leslie), who served in the kids' war, 1 want to say how pleased I was to meet him, and how difficult he has been to handle. 1 would not have liked to be the bearer who had the task of carrying him out of Tobruk. 1 am satisfied he would have had nothing in the hip pocket and he would have been very touchy in the hip pocket nerve, so that there would have been no return for the job. We have all been delighted to bc associated with him. Troublesome and all as he has been on occasions, he has only one. objective, the welfare of his country. I am sorry to see him go.

Now I come to the honorable member for Bonython (Mr. Makin). I have known him for a long time, perhaps too long. We have been together socially for years, arm in arm, agreeing to be divided politically. I am most indebted to the honorable member for Bonython, because, taking advantage of the fact that he was willing to be a temporary chairman of committees, I sucked his brains. He was of very great assistance to me. He has made a great contribution to the institution of Parliament and to the country he has so proudly represented. He has also made a great contribution to his party.

I served in the South Australian Parliament with my friend the honorable member for Port Adelaide (Mr. Thompson). He was known there as the whispering baritone. I can assure the House that anything that has been said about him tonight will be heartily endorsed not only by me but also by everybody else who has served with the honorable member. He is conscientious, honorable and straightforward, and I would say that in Port Adelaide he was impossible to shift.

We are all sorry that our friend from Cunningham (Mr. Kearney) is not here tonight. I am certain that we have all been pleased to meet him and be associated with him. He may not have had as much service, in either the Federal or State spheres, as other honorable members have had, but the contributions that he made in this place were always worthwhile. 1 am sure that he established many friends here, and although he is not with us at the moment he will, I believe, appreciate the fact that on this occasion we have expressed our appreciation of his contributions in this Parliament.

I am delighted to have had the opportunity of saying these few words, lt has been a very great privilege for mc to have been associated with the members of this Parliament, and I may say, facetiously, that I have discovered a new unity ticket, Holt and Daly.

talk.start.para: . - I have just realized, Mr. Speaker, as I walked up to the table, took my stand at attention and looked around, that this is the last occasion on which I shall do so. It makes one realize exactly what a break this represents in one's life. Although it is not usual on an occasion such as this for other members to speak after the leaders have spoken, I hope that in the present circumstances honorable members will bear with me for just a few moments.

speech.para: First, I would like to express my thanks to the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. McEwen), for the comments they have made about my service and the good wishes they have expressed for me in the future.

I appreciate that very much indeed, lt is natural for me to say that on an occasion like this my thoughts go back a little further than just this last sessional period of this Parliament. I have been thinking that, first, we pay a tribute to the service we have received from those who have graced the Chair. Through my own experience I can go back to the time of Sol Rosevear, then of Archie Cameron and then of yourself - three different types, but all giving great service to this House.

talk.start.para: - All bushrangers.
- Did 1 hear some one use the term " bushranger "?
- I am sure that the Minister's hearing is too sharp.

- If 1 were invited to start referring to personalities, I could tell this story. At one time we used to stay in Canberra and play cricket at the week-ends. One day the honorable member for FrankJin (Mr. Falkinder) hit the ball on to Mr. Speaker, lt just flicked off the bat. I thought, as a cricketer, " Wc have killed him ". But he just stood up and said, " Go on, she's right". He is not a bushranger, but he is very tough and very decent.

speech.para: I have also had the privilege in my duties of receiving the assistance of the Clerk and the Assistant Clerks. 1 want to ally myself with the remarks made by previous speakers as to the great service our Parliament gets and the service that members get from these officers.

talk.start.para: - When are you going to clean the Post Office?

speech.para: Mr. SPEAKER__ The honorable member is out of order.

talk.start.para: - It will be realized that 1 have had many and varied experiences in my life. However, I have had no experience more satisfying than that of the last seventeen years, since I have been a member of this House. In that time I had the privilege of seeing the leadership of the late Ben Chifley, when we were in Opposition. I learned quite a lot from that. Since then I have had the privilege of serving under our present great leader. I am not being political, or anything of that sort. I am paying a tribute to a man I believe to be one of the finest leaders Australia has ever produced. I have also had the privilege of serving under the leader of my own party. I have been privileged to make friendships - close friendships - with people on both sides of the House. I know that they will last for the rest of my life. I shall treasure them. I hope that because I am retiring reasonably early I shall be able to continue to enjoy those friendships. I hope to come back amongst you and say, " How are you getting on? "

speech.para: I cannot help thinking, when I refer to leaders, that it is only two nights ago that the " 46'ers " - as we call ourselves - got together for a dinner. When I retire there will be only two " 46'ers " left in the House of Representatives and in the Senate. That makes one think. I say now very sincerely that I have appreciated greatly my service with you and the value of the great friendships which I have formed. Sir, when I walk out to-night I shall, with a great deal of respect, make my last bow to you.

talk.start.para: .- This is possibly the most difficult speech that I have ever been required to make. Words are quite inadequate for me to express to the House and to the country the deep sense of gratitude I feel for the high honours that have been bestowed on me and the goodwill that has been made manifest to me. I thank the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies), the Leader of the Opposition (Mr. Calwell), the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. McEwen) and yourself, Sir, for the most generous remarks that have been made regarding my service to this country. I endeavoured to give the devoted service that was expected of me. I want to say how deeply I appreciate all of the great friendships that have been made possible to me in this House, and how delighted I was with the service I was able to give to this country as Australian Ambassador to the United States of America. I was privileged to serve both sides of the Parliament in the performance of the duties of that high and responsible office.

speech.para: I am grateful, as I have said, for all of the generous remarks that have been made about me. I have served in fourteen parliaments of the Commonwealth of Australia over a period of 35 years. When 1 came here, I was the youngest man in the House. I was then 29 years of age. I was regarded in those days as far too young to have come into the Parliament. I remember the late honorable member for Wakefield saying, "He is but a child in swaddling clothes politically". 1 might have given evidence of it, but at the same time I sought to give the service worthy of one seeking to serve the country that he loves.

On my entrance to the Parliament, in Melbourne, I was challenged at the door by a messenger. He wanted to know what was my business. I indicated to him that I had come to work there. He possibly thought that I was a tradesman who had come to repair the faucets in the building, and said that I had no right to go through certain doors, not possessing any rights other than those of a tradesman. However,. I pointed out that 1 was the new member for Hindmarsh. That made some difference. I served an apprenticeship. I was not at that moment a tradesman in right of my political knowledge, but 1 trust that over the years I have shown, some evidence that the experience 1 gained in public life has been of some value.

I want to express, through you, Sir, to all members of the House and to the staffs of all departments my deep appreciation of all the courtesies and kindnesses shown to me. lt would be impossible for me to enumerate all of those to whom I feel indebted, but I can assure you that the wonderful expressions of goodwill and friendship extended to me from both sides of the House and from all departments of the House will be a cherished memory with me for the rest of my time. I warmly reciprocate those expressions of goodwill and friendship.

May I be permitted to offer my final words to the country in this, the parliament of the Australian people. The people of this country have a great heritage to preserve. No public man can afford to be indifferent to its protection. Great suffering and sacrifice have marked the road to the attainment of our nationhood. Our history, brief as it may be, has written in every line endurance and perseverance. The ordinary people, the people who exercise themselves in the work of this nation, be they in the workshop or on the farm, have chosen over the years to build in this continent a new way of life. We still lack the economic security and the social well-being that a country potentially so rich in all natural resources can afford for its people. Much pioneering work is to be done and vast works are to be accomplished. This is the challenge of these times.

There are in the Australian a capacity and a courage to fulfil those great ambitions, and so 1 have no fears for the future. Governments that are unprogressive or unimaginative may delay for a brief season the course of these events, but can never destroy the resolve of a proud and confident people. Therefore, I leave the Parliament in which I have sought to serve the Australian nation and its people believing that the destiny of this Parliament is inseparably linked with the party that 1 have had the privilege of serving - the Australian Labour Party. 1 am proud to have served in a movement so dedicated and under leadership so stimulating and inspiring. My final words are: Thank you all, and may God bless this, my native land - Australia.

Mr. DRUMMOND (New England) 19.12]. - Mr. Speaker, first of all, 1 thank you for your personal references and the sentiments that you expressed. I shall not attempt to add to those eloquent words spoken by you, the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) and the Deputy Prime Minister (Mr. McEwen) on the subject of the services rendered by the officers of the House. I would say to all members of the parliamentary staffs, in brief, that I extend my warmest thanks for their help and assistance during my term in this parliament.

After almost 30 years as a member of the New South Wales Parliament, it was a most interesting experience for me to enter the Parliament of the nation and to appreciate to the full many things of which 1 had only a glimmering of knowledge before, especially the extraordinary complexity of the problems that confront the leaders of a nation composed of six States occupying this vast continent. A greater understanding of those things makes for mutual tolerance between the States and the Commonwealth of one another's points of view.

The honorable member for Bonython (Mr. Makin) mentioned the disability under which he laboured when he first attempted to enter the Federal Parliament. I first attempted to enter this Parliament, in one sense, in company with a man who shortly afterwards became Deputy Premier of New South Wales. This was soon after the late King George V. bad opened this building. As we reached the top of the steps in front, a gentleman at the door said " Where are your passes?" We produced our State parliamentary passes and said that we were State members. He said, " State members are of no account here". We retreated a few steps well out of his reach, and I said to my friend, " Let us not argue with this low fellow ". So we went off, attempting as best we could to carry the honours of the day.

Subsequently, T came into this Parliament as a member. After almost fourteen years here, I should like to say, first of all, that I have found it a great privilege to serve in a Parliament in which one who, I believe, is probably the most distinguished and brilliant parliamentarian in the British Commonwealth of Nations, serves as Prime Minister of this country. It has been a great privilege to serve under two leaders of the Australian Country Party - Sir Arthur Fadden and the present leader, the Right Honorable John McEwen. I have found it a great privilege also to serve on committees such as the Foreign Affairs Committee, and the committee appointed by the Prime Minister to prepare the blueprint for the National Library of Australia. Above and beyond everything else, it was a great and very satisfying experience for me to serve on the all-party Constitutional Review Committee. On that committee, I served for a number of years with mcn on both sides of the Parliament. When one serves on a committee like that over so long a period, one gets a very much better understanding of a subject that is very far-reaching indeed.

The Prime Minister very kindly mentioned the fact that I had devoted a lifetime to trying to bring about the formation of new States in this country. His remarks were supplemented by my leader. May I say that I started my first campaign in 1919 at the age of 29, and it end id satisfactorily in March, 1920. That campaign was one of the things that convinced me of what is perhaps the most important issue in the life of Australia. One of the sad things for mc, as I leave this Parliament, Sir, is that, after more than 40 years of unremitting struggle by myself and my friends, I find that the things that we forecast arc happening to the detriment of this nation. Great masses of population are being built up in vulnerable cities with great concentrations of industry, and our hinterland is left relatively undeveloped.

I do not wish to take that line of thought too tar now. But having, with my colleagues on both sides of the House, studied the defects of our Constitution, may I take the role of a prophet and say that, at the rate at which constitutional pressure has been exerted on us since the war - it has accelerated particularly in the last few years - the constitutional reform that this country will have to undertake for the sake of its own preservation and future development will make the reforms that we recommended pale into insignificance. In saying that, I do not for one moment wish to convey the idea that I believe that the principle of federalism is wrong. I believe that federalism and our relations with the States must be the subject of a tremendous change, probably within the next decade, not because we are becoming more alert, but because the march of events will force us to make changes.

I go out of this Parliament, Sir, regretting that in that respect I have not been able to achieve as much as I had hoped to achieve. I know that there has always been a deep conviction on the part of those people who have laboured with me. Some have crossed the Great Divide and others will soon follow. They have been strong and dour in their determination. My friend, the Prime Minister, has mentioned St. Andrew's Day, bringing up thoughts of the Scots. New England was settled mainly by Scots. They are a very dour and determined people. When they set out after anything, they do not let up until they get it. That is proved by more than 44 years of continuous struggle and effort by every constitutional means we possess to obtain what is necessary for this country.

Perhaps I have trespassed somewhat too long on the courtesy of the House. I thank all with whom I have been associated here for what they have contributed to our mutual association. I have spoken mainly on a serious note. Let me now conclude by quoting some words which are sung as a hymn in the Presbyterian Church and which were written as a prayer by an outstanding Roman Catholic -

quote.para: From all that terror teaches. From lies of tongue and pen, From all the easy speeches That comfort cruel men. From sale and profanation Of honour and the sword, From sleep and from damnation. Deliver us, good Lord

speech.para: That is my prayer for the country which I love and which I have endeavoured to serve to the best of my ability.

talk.start.para: . - I 'regret that I have a bad throat to-night. Instead of a whispering baritone, I am but a croaking frog. I thank the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) and other honorable members who have referred to my work, for their kind words.

speech.para: I have learned some very useful lessons during my parliamentary career. I have had 33* years' experience in State and Federal parliaments. In that period I sat on the government side for only six years; sp that I have had 27* years' experience in opposition. While, I was a member of the State Parliament in South Australia I decided that if I were not able to achieve anything as a member of my party's government then the best I could do would be to set out to gain as much as I could from the government that was in office. I say to the Prime Minister now, that all through that time when I wanted anything, I always took great care not to abuse the relevant Minister, or the government, but to put up the strongest case that I could in an endeavour to persuade both the Minister and the government that 1 was right.

For the first three years of my career as a member of this House, a Labour government was in office. Since then an antiLabour government has occupied the treasury bench. After those first three years, I made up my mind that if I could not see a Labour government in office, I would work strenuously to get as much as I could from whatever government was in power. One of the greatest sources of pleasure to me is to recall the fact that, during my long experience as a parliamentarian, many things that I initiated in both the Federal and State spheres were supported by others, and even though I did not happen to be a member of the government of the day, they have been brought to fruition. Ever since I entered the Parliament it has been my belief that the paramount duty of a member of parliament is to do everything he possibly could to foster the progress of his country and to further the welfare of its people.

We all have our own policies. We on this side argue that the Government's policy is not as good as the Labour Party's policy, but I am a firm believer in the democratic principle that once the vote is taken at an election the successful party must be given the right and the opportunity to govern. Acknowledging that principle, it is then my duty te see what I can do to influence the successful party or parties to govern in the way that I think it or they should govern.

It is a great pleasure to be here to-night with my colleague, the honorable member for Bonython (Mr. Makin), bidding farewell to you all. He has had a little longer service than I have in this Parliament, but he also served as our ambassador overseas for a time. During the whole of the time that I was a member of the South Australian Parliament, my electorate embraced a portion of the division represented by the honorable member for Bonython and for that reason we had to work very closely together. When the honorable member for Bonython resigned to take office as our ambassador in the United States of America there was a tremendous battle in South Australia amongst those who sought to take his place in this parliament. In those days, it was thought that the best and safest seat to hold was the Hindmarsh seat, which he then held. After a long and hard battle, 1 was successful in being selected to take his place in this Parliament. Then, a few years after the honorable member returned from the United Slates we were together again, and I have been associated with him ever since. I know the high ideals he has. He is a better man than I am. I have always seemed to do more things wrongly than he does. Because I have had the highest regard for the ideals that animate him, we have been able to go through life together as great friends. I challenge anyone who examines our political careers to point to any occasion on which we have fallen down on the job or hit below the belt. I am inclined at times to have a hit at somebody, but 1 have always hit fairly.

I say quite candidly that 1 am disappointed to be leaving the Parliament at this time, and I blame the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) for that disappointment, though I thank him for what he has said about me. I had made up my mind to leave this Parliament in twelve months' time after having completed the period for which I was elected. But what happened? The Prime Minister has said to mc, " You are gone ".

I feci like a chap who is building a house and who, having completed the foundation work and erected the walls is ready to set to work painting it, so that he may be able to say, " That is finished ", only to have the house taken away from him. I have not been able to finish my task. I cannot go out among my constituents and say that my job in the parliament is finished. I have not been able to do the things I wanted to do. I have been prevented from completing my work. Of course, it is not entirely the Prime Minister's fault; other factors have been responsible for my not standing for reelection.

I regret very much that I shall not be here next year sitting behind the Labour government because there are many things the Labour Party wants to do and, candidly, I should like to have a finger in the pie. I should like to help to have these things done. I appreciate the goodwill extended to me by all honorable . members here. 1 appreciate greatly the friendship and the goodwill that honorable members on the Government side have always shown towards me. J have always felt that 1 ha.'e been one of a family gathering.

For about thirteen years, I was the parliamentary representative on the council of the University of Adelaide. There I mixed with some of the most highly educated men in Adelaide and some of its most successful legal and business men. In all, there were 25 members of that council and although I had never had one single day's secondary education these learned men accepted mc. They judged a man not by the school tie that he wore but by the manner in which he carried out the duties of his position. When I came to this Parliament, I had to leave the . council. It was a tremendous wrench to end an association with men who, although they were on the highest rung of the educational and social ladder, and I was on the bottom rung, treated me as an equal. When 1 was a member of the State Parliament, I served on select committees and found that I could work with members of the other side of politics just as well as I could work with members on my own side in dealing with big national questions.

My time is finished. I am now going by the wayside, as it were, but I am looking forward to seeing done everything that it is possible to do in the interests of the betterment of our country. All through my parliamentary career I have held the view that my task was not to represent big business interests. I have always made the welfare of the common men in the community my special responsibility. If I have failed to achieve my ends, then all I can say is that I did my best.

I wish all honorable members a very happy festive season. I advise honorable members opposite to put up a good fight at the election. If they do not do so they will get an even worse licking than they will if they fight hard.

I come now to my leader, Mr. Calwell, whom I have known very intimately in the Labour movement since about 1930. The Labour Party is very fortunate in having a man of such high principles as its leader. He is animated by the highest Christian principles. Whenever, as a member of the South Australian Parliament, I took school children to see the Parliament at work, 1 was always proud to boast to them that each day the proceedings are opened by the recital of the Lord's Prayer. This is a Christian parliament and although some of us may not be very good Christians I feel that so long as Parliament continues to commence its day's work in this way something worth while will be achieved for the nation. I thank all honorable members and extend my good wishes to them all in their future life.

talk.start.para: .- I frankly confess that this is not an occasion when it is easy to make a speech, but it is a unique occasion in the sense that it affords to those who choose to retire from Parliament an opportunity to express their appreciation publicly and to pay public tribute to all those to whom they feel they owe a debt for the help which has made it possible for them to carry out their parliamentary duties. I want to take advantage of this opportunity to pay a tribute - I do not think any member of the Parliament would disagree with me - to the wives of members. I pay a special tribute to the grandest lady in Australia - my own wife. I could never have entered public life without her loyalty and her help, and I could never have gone as far as I have without her. As members of Parliament, we have our moments of glory and are treated as V.I.P.'s; but the burden and the heat of the day is borne by the wife and the family. I pay this tribute to my own good lady and I pay the same tribute to the lady of every member of the Parliament, especially to those who come from distant parts.

speech.para: The public and the press - I do not know which it is - are anxious to sec youth at the helm. Youth in this Parliament, in either part of it, would need to be gifted beyond the normal measure to serve this country. Any one seeking to become a member of the Parliament must be prepared to make sacrifices. Family life must become a secondary consideration. Because of this, I believe that we should pay our first tribute to the wives and families of members.

Mr. Speaker, you were kind enough to refer to me. After a parliamentary life a member carries away a lot of memories, which consist of little shining lights with one or two beacons. I would like to mention one special memory that I will carry away with me. I want to pay a tribute, first, to your predecessor, the late Archie Cameron, who, as Speaker, helped me when I came into this House. 1 knew him before I came here; he used to visit Western Australia. I pay him a tribute for the help he gave me. I want to thank you, Sir, for the help you have given me. The shining beacon in the memories of my parliamentary life will be an occasion many years ago when some one brushed against my side as I walked away from the airport terminal and said, "Here, Pegleg, give me your bag ".. It was you, Mr. Speaker.

Physically handicapped people resent this sort of thing, because we feel that there is the suggestion of helplessness behind it. However, I recalled the meritorious service you had given to your mates and my mates as a stretcher bearer in the First World War. I took your offer as evidence of the continuation of the spirit you had shown in your service during the war. For years afterwards, I felt humble and proud every week-end when you searched me out from amongst the air passengers to carry my bag. Your comment, "Pegleg, give me your bag", will remain in my memory as a shining beacon. It shows your compassion, your understanding and your willingness to help your fellow man. I would remember nothing more. 1 would say thank you for that and thank you for the assistance you have given me in this place.

I want to thank each of the Ministers. They have been a very great help and guidance to me. Without their help, a member of Parliament cannot give satisfaction to his electors. I pay a tribute to the departmental officers for their forbearance, their understanding and their efforts to explain to members the complexities of departmental work. They give this assistance whether the member belongs to the Australian Country Party, the Liberal Party or the Australian Labour Party. It is their job and it is a conscientious effort to give satisfaction to the member and service to their country.

I want to say thank you to honorable members. I have formed some very good friendships here. Another highlight that will remain conspicuously in my memory is the warm reception accorded to me when I returned to the Parliament after a short period in the wilderness. When I rose to make my first speech after my return to this House, Opposition members gave me an ovation which, I am told, was exceptional in this Parliament. I am proud of that. I differ from Opposition members and I have fought them, but that is a circumstance of parliamentary life.

One aspect that I regret is that in this Parliament party divisions are carried outside this chamber. I came to this Parliament from the State Parliament, where we had our differences inside the chamber and on the hustings, but when we met outside the chamber we greeted each other as Bill Brown, Charlie Smith or whatever the name may bc, and sat at the same tables. The country does not benefit from the fact that Labour members, Country Party members and Liberal Party members sit at different tables in the dining room here. I hate to think that I must eat party politics with my porridge. When I first came to Canberra in 1949, I went with my wife to the dining room in the hotel to have lunch. After I had mentioned my name, we were led to a table. The hostess or the lady in charge of the dining room - whatever she may bc called- said, " What are you? " I said, " I am a member of Parliament ". She said, " I do not mean that. To what party do you belong? " I said, " To the Country

Party ". She said, " You cannot sit here; you have to sit over there ". That is what happens here and I regret that it does. Every political group has its own show, but I believe that we should mix and have companionship outside the chamber. After all, we are members of a parliamentary union.

I do not want to take advantage of the opportunity I have been given by speaking for too long. I want to thank the staff of the Parliament. By the staff I mean the Clerk of the House and those who are with him. They have helped me as they have helped others. I want to say a sincere thank you to " Hansard ". On one occasion I heard the Prime Minister (Sir Robert Menzies) say that he did not read the proofs of his speeches. I have never read the proofs of my speeches, and I thank "Hansard" for having made my speeches jolly good ones.

talk.start.para: - Perhaps you did not recognize them as being your own.
- I agree. I could not recognize them afterwards; they were very good.

speech.para: I want to thank the staff of the Joint House Department and the staff of the dining room for their courtesies and for going out of their way to help me. I think mention of the telephone staff would not be amiss. I believe the manner in which they recognize a voice is fantastic. They render a very good service and I think we owe them a debt of gratitude.

talk.start.para: - Is. this why we can never get through to Western Australia?

- That is right. Speaking more seriously, I should like to say one or two things before I go because, after all is said and done, honorable members will not have the privilege - or the opposite - of hearing me in future. I first entered a parliament - the Parliament of Western Australia - with a purpose in view. I did not go into the Parliament just because I wanted to be a member of Parliament. I had one purpose only, and that was to defeat a section of the people - not the government - who in my opinion were denying the development of the portion of Western Australia in which I lived. I went into the State Parliament to secure a comprehensive water scheme in an area the development of which was being hindered by the attitude of those whom I went into the Parliament to represent. Wc got the water scheme, and perhaps I should have then gone out of the Parliament, but since I have found other objectives.

speech.para: I entered the Commonwealth Parliament with the object of looking at our financial system. Well, we have the Public Accounts Committee. 1 regret that 1 go out of this Parliament with unfinished business, but I hope that somebody will take up this question and fight for the establishment of an estimates committee on the lines of that in the United Kingdom Parliament. I hope - in fact 1 am sure- that my successor will fight for the extension of the comprehensive water scheme in Western Australia. I have already started lobbying on behalf of my pet hobby, the rehabilitation of the physically handicapped people of Australia. I hope somebody will take up that matter and urge the Government to tackle this problem in the only way in which it can be tackled. The complexities and ramifications of the needs of the physically handicapped of all kinds are too great to be mct piecemeal - one small section at a time. This matter must be handled in one way only, that is, by the appointment of a committee comprised of a wide section of the Parliament to investigate the requirements of the physically handicapped. Theirs is an urgent need, and T regret that I will not be here to do something in this regard, but I have already started lobbying in this matter.
As I go out of this Parliament, perhaps I can say with safety that I believe that the life of the Parliament should be five years and not three years.

talk.start.para: - Not five years!

- Yes, five years. I know that a sitting member is suspect straight away if he makes this suggestion. It is said that he is trying to extend his period another two years. When a government comes into power it takes it twelve months to find* out what is going on. It takes the next year for the government to introduce its policy and the third year may well be spent in making preparation for the next election.
- That is nonsense.

- lt is not nonsense, and I challenge the Leader of the Opposition on that point. If there were five years and not three years between elections the country would develop. I hope some sitting member in this Parliament will have courage enough to get up and tell the country that a three years' term is detrimental and that the term should be five years.

speech.para: I want now to preach to my fellow members in these terms: For goodness sake watch the operations of Parliament! Remember - that! Members of parliament are here to make decisions and I believe there is a danger inherent in the way we arc going at present. There is a danger that the effectiveness of Parliament may be lost through the dominance of the Executive instead of the dominance of members of parliament. I do not believe it is right - 1 do not say it happens here, although it could - that the Executive should come to members of parliament and say, " This is our will and this is what you will do ". I believe it is the job of the Executive to say: " This is what we recommend. Tell us where to go and we will get on with the job." I come now to a quotation which I heard recently and which made a terrific impression on me because it is one of the most truthful things one could hear. It is -
Their endeavours of yesterday made possible our to-day.
It is your responsibility to ensure that there will be a to-morrow.
Finally, may I express to all honorable members the wish that those who deserve to come back to this Parliament will return to it.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
House adjourned at 9.46 p.m. until a date and hour to be fixed by Mr. Speaker and to be notified by him to each member by telegram or letter.

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice -

item.para: Is there a grave shortage of doctors in Australia, particularly in rural areas?

Yes. However, it must be borne in mind that the proportion of enrolments in medicine at the universities is influenced by the proportions enrolled in other faculties. During the period from 1951 to 1961 there was considerable expansion of university facilities, including the provision of new and modified courses. For very good reasons, there have been increases in the proportions of students undertaking, for example, ' courses in science, technology and commerce. Inevitably, this has led to a decline in the proportion studying medicine. A much more significant fact is that in proportion to the population of Australia there were more students enrolled in faculties of medicine in 1961 than there were in 1951.

The University of Melbourne will increase its annual intake of medical students from 160 to 240 by 1967. The University of Tasmania will establish a medical school to lake first year students in 1966. Expansion of the new medical schools at the University of New South Wales and Monash University will continue. All of these developments are being aided by very substantial Commonwealth grants.

The Commonwealth Scholarships Board has from time to time considered the question of warding proportions of available Commonwealth scholarships specifically for certain faculties, but : has decided against doing so. Any student who is selected as a Commonwealth scholar is entitled to elect to study medicine if he is able to gain admission to a faculty of medicine at a university.
